revision.comment: /* Impact */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[File:Pipelines in Eastern Europe.png|thumb|300px|[[Druzhba pipeline]] goes from Russia through Belarus to other European countries]] The '''Russia–Belarus energy dispute''' began when [[Russia]]n [[state-owned]] [[natural gas|gas]] supplier [[Gazprom]] demanded an increase in gas prices paid by [[Belarus]], a country which has been closely allied with Moscow and forms a loose [[Union State|union state]] with Russia. It escalated on 8 January 2007, when the Russian state-owned pipeline company [[Transneft]] stopped pumping [[petroleum|oil]] into the [[Druzhba pipeline]] which runs through [[Belarus]] because Belarus was siphoning the oil off the pipe without mutual agreement.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6240473.stm |title=Russia oil row hits Europe supply |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110001702/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6240473.stm |archivedate=10 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> <ref name="upstream russianoil">{{cite news |url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/europe/article125800.ece |title=Russian oil flows via Belarus halted |publisher=Upstreamonline |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-09 | subscription = yes }}</ref> On 10 January, Transneft resumed oil exports through the pipeline after Belarus ended the tariff that sparked the shutdown, despite differing messages from the parties on the state of negotiations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globalinsight.com/SDA/SDADetail8016.htm |title=Belarus Cancels Oil Transit Tax; Druzhba Oil Deliveries Resumed |publisher=[[Global Insight]] |date=2007-01-11 |accessdate=2007-01-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/10/AR2007011002094.html |title=Russia-Belarus Standoff Over Oil Ends, Clearing Way for Accord |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date=2007-01-11 |accessdate=2007-01-11 | first=Peter | last=Finn}}</ref>
The Druzhba pipeline, the world's longest, supplies around 20% of Germany's oil.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article125765.ece |title=Belarus steps back from brink |publisher=Upstreamonline |date=2007-01-05 |accessdate=2007-01-09 | subscription = yes }}</ref> It also supplies oil to [[Poland]], [[Ukraine]], [[Slovakia]], the [[Czech Republic]], and [[Hungary]].
==Background== [[File:Oil pipelines in Europe.png|thumb|300px|Oil pipelines in Europe and Northwestern Asia.]] For a long time, the gas price for most of the former USSR republics was significantly lower than for the Western European countries. In 2006 Belarus paid only $46 per 1000 m³, a fraction compared to $290 per 1000 m³ paid by Germany.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/200604/17/eng20060417_258874.html |title=Russia to adopt market gas price with Belarus from 2007 |publisher=[[People's Daily]] |date=2006-04-17 |accessdate=2007-05-19}}</ref> The annual Russian subsidies to the Belarusian economy were around $4 billion, as Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] said on 9 January 2007. In 2006 Russia announced a higher price for 2007. After [[Alexander Lukashenko]], President of Belarus, rejected this price change, and without a new treaty, Gazprom threatened to cut gas supplies to [[Belarus]] from 10:00 [[Moscow Time|MSK]] on 1 January 2007. Both sides finally agreed on the following terms: *Russian gas to be sold to Belarus for $100 per 1000 m³ (compared to Gazprom's original request of $200 per 1000 m³) *Belarus to sell Gazprom 50% of its national gas supplier [[Beltransgaz]] for the maximal price of $2.5 billion <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6189379.stm |title=Russian gas demands irk Belarus |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2006-12-18 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110202051/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6189379.stm |archivedate=10 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> *Gas prices for Belarus to gradually rise to the European market price by 2011 *Belarus's transit fees for Russian gas to increase by around 70% <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6221835.stm |title=Russia-Belarus gas deal reached |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2006-12-31 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070108112958/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6221835.stm |archivedate=8 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
Another part of the energy dispute is the dispute over oil. In 1995, Russia and Belarus agreed that Russia would not impose any customs on oil exported to Belarus. In exchange, the revenues from this oil processed in Belarus would be shared by 15% for Belarus and 85% for Russia. In 2001, Belarus unilaterally canceled this agreement while Russia continued its duty-free exports. Lukashenko's state kept all the revenues, and many Russian oil companies moved their processing capacities to Belarus. On this arrangement, Russia also lost billions of dollars annually. Belarus imposed a tariff of US$45 per ton of [[petroleum|oil]] flowing through the Druzhba pipeline, prompting Russia to claim that the move was illegal and to threaten retaliation,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070106/bs_afp/belarusrussiaenergy |title=Belarus, Russia trade blows in oil tax dispute |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-01-06 |accessdate=2007-01-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> since it contradicts bilateral trade agreements and worldwide practice. Only imported or exported goods are being tariffed while transit goods are not objects of tariffing. Russia rejected paying the newly imposed Belarusian tariffs.<ref name="oilrow">{{cite news|title=Russia oil row hits Europe supply |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6240473.stm |publisher=''[[BBC]]'' |accessdate=2007-01-10 |date=2007-01-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110082008/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6240473.stm |archivedate=10 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
In compensation, Belarus began siphoning off oil from the pipeline.<ref name="oilrow" /> According to [[Semyon Vainshtok]], the head of Russia's pipeline monopoly [[Transneft]], Belarus had siphoned off 79,900 metric tons of oil since 6 January. Vainshtok said this was illegal and the move was made "without warning anyone."<ref name="heraldtribune">{{cite news |author=Steven Lee Myers |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/01/08/business/belarus.php |title=Belarus and Russia spar over crude oil cutoff |publisher=[[International Herald Tribune]] |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109185842/http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/01/08/business/belarus.php |archivedate=9 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> In response, Russia stopped oil transport on 8 January.<ref name="oilrow" /><ref name="BBCRussian">{{cite news|title=Белoруссия отменила транзитную пошлину |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/russia/newsid_6248000/6248293.stm |publisher=''[[BBC]]'' |accessdate=2007-01-10 |date=2007-01-10 |language=Russian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070112102204/http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/russia/newsid_6248000/6248293.stm |archivedate=12 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
A Belarusian team led by Vice-Premier [[Andrei Kobyakov]] flew to [[Moscow]] on 9 January to pursue a solution<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070109.wbelaruss0109/BNStory/International/home |title=Russian oil flows via Belarus halted |publisher=globeandmail.com |date=2007-01-09 |accessdate=2007-01-09 }}</ref> but initially reported that they had not been able to start negotiations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/R/RUSSIA_BELARUS_OIL |title=Russia Cabinet Told to Weigh Output Cut |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-01-09 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070112235833/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/R/RUSSIA_BELARUS_OIL |archivedate=12 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 10 January, the Belarusian government lifted the tariff, and Russia agreed to start negotiations.<ref name="BBCRussian" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Russia says oil flow to restart |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6248251.stm |publisher=''[[BBC]]'' |accessdate=2007-01-10 |date=2006-01-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070112091923/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6248251.stm |archivedate=12 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The oil flow was resumed at 05:30 [[GMT]] on 11 January.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia-Belarus oil blockade ends |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6248251.stm |publisher=''[[BBC]]'' |accessdate=2007-01-11 |date=2007-01-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070112091923/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6248251.stm |archivedate=12 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> In the wake of the dispute, Gazprom acquired 50% stake in the Belarusian gas pipeline operator [[Beltransgaz]] for 2.5 Billion USD.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gazprom Buys Half of Beltransgaz for $2.5 Billion |url=http://www.kommersant.com/p-10746/natural_gas/ |publisher=''[[Kommersant]]'' |accessdate=2007-05-19 |date=2007-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184559/http://www.kommersant.com/p-10746/natural_gas/ |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==August 2007 developments== Following the alleged violation of previous agreements and the failure of negotiations, on 1 August 2007 [[Gazprom]] announced that it would cut gas supplies to [[Belarus]] by 45% from 3 August over a $456 million debt.<ref name=Reuters070801>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL019104720070801 |accessdate=2007-08-01 |work=Reuters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017191033/http://reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL019104720070801 |title=UPDATE 4-Gazprom to halve gas to Belarus in debt row |archivedate=17 October 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Talks are continuing and Belarus has asked for more time to pay. Although the revived dispute is not expected to hit supplies to Europe, the [[European Commission]] is said to view the situation 'very seriously'.<ref name=Reuters070801 /> Following overnight negotiations in Moscow, on 3 August, $190 million of the debt was repaid, and Belarus was given a further week to pay the remainder or face a 30% cut in supplies.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL0347959120070803 | accessdate = 2007-08-03 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 4-Belarus buys one week's respite in Russia gas row | date=2007-08-03}}</ref>
As of 8 August Belarus has fully paid its $460 million debt for Russian natural gas supplies, ending a dispute between the country and Gazprom [RTS: GAZP].
==Related disputes== The situation is reminiscent of other recent price tensions between Russia, one of the world's [[energy superpower]]s, and other states since the start of 2005. These have resulted in increases in the prices paid for gas by [[Moldova]] (now paying US$170 per 1,000 cubic meter<ref>[http://www.akm.ru/eng/news/2006/december/26/ns1840485.htm Gazprom to deliver gas to Moldavia at $170 per 1,000 cubic meters in 2007], by AK&M, 26 December 2006. Retrieved on 11 January 2007</ref>), [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] (US$235 per 1,000 cubic meter<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6203721.stm |title=Georgia 'agrees Russia gas bill' |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2006-12-22 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109181034/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6203721.stm |archivedate=9 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>) and [[Ukraine]] (following the 2006 [[Russia-Ukraine gas dispute]], which also resulted in a 4-day cut to [[Europe]]an gas supplies).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6207257.stm |title=Azeris warn Russia on gas prices |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2006-12-24 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |first=Matthew |last=Collin |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070119195334/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6207257.stm |archivedate=19 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><!--DASHBot-->| with Azerbaijan having recently stopped oil exports to Russia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/1/BF304083-C0C9-43A3-9177-AB11CE785BBB.html |title=Azerbaijan halts oil exports to Russia |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]] |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109220419/http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/1/BF304083-C0C9-43A3-9177-AB11CE785BBB.html |archivedate=9 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 29 July 2006 Russia shut down oil export to [[Mažeikių Nafta|Mažeikių oil refinery]] in [[Lithuania]] after an oil spill on the Druzhba pipeline system occurred in Russia’s [[Bryansk Oblast|Bryansk oblast]], near the point where a line to Belarus and Lithuania branches off the main export pipeline. Transneft said it would need one year and nine months to repair the damaged section. Although Russia cited technical reasons for stopping oil deliveries to Lithuania, Lithuania claims that the oil supply was stopped because Lithuania sold the Mažeikių refinery to Polish company [[PKN Orlen]].<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=414&issue_id=3822&article_id=2371343 Russian oil supplies to Lithuania cut off] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061121034522/http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=414&issue_id=3822&article_id=2371343 |date=21 November 2006 }}, by Vladimis Socor, Eurasia Daily Monitor Volume 3, Issue 150 (3 August 2006)</ref>
==Impact== All [[International Energy Agency|IEA]] member countries who are net oil importers have legal obligation to hold emergency oil reserves, which is equivalent to at least 90 days of net oil imports of the previous year.<ref>[http://www.iea.org/textbase/papers/2004/factsheetcover.pdf Fact Sheet on IEA Oil Stocks and Response Potential]</ref> Furthermore, under the EU regulations there is obligation to hold reserves equivalent to 90 days of consumption, so unlike the gas dispute with Ukraine in 2006, consumers were not affected. Poland had an 80-day oil reserve.<ref name="oilrow" /> The Czech Republic reported drawing oil from its 100-day reserves.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globalinsight.com/SDA/SDADetail8001.htm |title=European Leaders Fire Up Over Russian Oil Cut |publisher=[[Global Insights]] |date=2007-01-10 |accessdate=2007-01-10 }}</ref> Had the dispute prolonged, it is likely that alternative supplies would have been secured. International oil prices were not significantly affected.
The involved countries have, however, expressed concerns about the reliability of the Russia-Belarus oil pipeline and Belarus as an oil middleman supplier.
The events have also provoked renewed discussion on the government policy of phasing out [[nuclear power in Germany]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2304599,00.html |title=Merkel Puts Germany's Nuclear Phase-Out in Question |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=2007-01-09 |accessdate=2007-01-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070112070234/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0%2C2144%2C2304599%2C00.html |archivedate=12 January 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Reaction== The [[European Union]] has demanded an "urgent and detailed" explanation, according to a spokesman for Energy Commissioner [[Andris Piebalgs]].<ref name="upstream russianoil"/>
[[Piotr Naimski]], [[Poland]]'s deputy economics minister who is responsible for [[energy security]], stated "This shows once again that arguments among various countries of the former Soviet Union between suppliers and transit countries mean that these deliveries are unreliable from our perspective."<ref name="heraldtribune"/>
German Economy Minister [[Michael Glos]] stated that the dispute showed that "one-side dependencies must not be allowed to develop."<ref>{{cite news|author=Sebastian Smith |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070108/bs_afp/polandrussiabelarus_070108212931 |title=Russia-Belarus oil row hits supplies to Germany, Poland |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-09 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Following a meeting with [[European Commission]] President [[José Manuel Barroso]] in [[Berlin]], German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] condemned the action, stating "It is not acceptable when there are no consultations about such actions". Commenting on the importance of trust in energy security, she said "That always destroys trust and no trusting, undisturbed cooperation can be built on that." Merkel continued by saying "We will certainly say to our Russian partners but also to Belarus that such consultations are the minimum when there are problems, and I think that that must become normality, as it would be within the European Union." Barroso said that "while there is no immediate risk to supplies, it is not acceptable" for such actions to be undertaken without prior consultation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/01/09/europe/EU-GEN-Germany-EU-Energy.php |title=Merkel, Barroso say 'not acceptable' to halt energy deliveries without consultations |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-01-09 |accessdate=2007-01-09 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Energy}} *[[Foreign relations of Russia towards Belarus]] *[[2004 Russia–Belarus gas dispute]] *[[Russia-Ukraine gas dispute]] *[[Energy crisis]] *[[Nord Stream]], an undersea pipeline constructed to bypass transit countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mosnews.com/money/2005/12/30/iaeagainstpipeline.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20060103092957/http://www.mosnews.com/money/2005/12/30/iaeagainstpipeline.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-01-03 |title=International Energy Agency Speaks Out Against Russia’s Baltic Gas Pipeline |publisher=MosNews |date=2005-12-30 |accessdate=2007-01-09 }}</ref> *[[Energy Charter Treaty]], including principles for energy trade and transit which Russia is refusing to ratify. *[[Energy policy of Russia]] *[[Energy policy of the European Union]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061004021120/http://www.transneft.ru/Default.asp?LANG=EN Transneft], Russian state owned pipeline monopoly. *[http://www.btg.by Beltransgaz], Belarusian gas pipeline company.
{{DEFAULTSORT:2007 Russia-Belarus energy dispute}} [[Category:Politics of Russia]] [[Category:Politics of Belarus]] [[Category:Energy policy]] [[Category:Energy policy of Russia]] [[Category:Energy in Belarus]] [[Category:Belarus–Russia relations]] [[Category:Transneft]] [[Category:2007 in Belarus|Russia-Belarus Energy Dispute, 2007]] [[Category:2007 in Russia|Russia-Belarus Energy Dispute, 2007]] [[Category:2007 in international relations|Russia-Belarus Energy Dispute, 2007]] [[Category:Natural resource conflicts]] [[Category:Price disputes involving Gazprom]]

{{Year nav topic5|2=arthropod paleontology|3=science}} {{Portal|Paleontology|History of science}} This '''list of [[fossil]] [[arthropod]]s described in 2013''' is a list of new [[taxon|taxa]] of [[trilobite]]s, fossil [[insect]]s, [[crustacean]]s, [[arachnid]]s and other fossil arthropods of every kind that have been [[binomial nomenclature|described]] during the year 2013. The list only includes taxa at the level of [[genus]] or [[species]]. ==Arachnids== {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" width="100%" |- ! Name ! Novelty ! Status ! Authors ! Age ! Unit ! Location ! Notes ! Images |- | ''[[Amiracarus pliocennatus]]''{{cite journal |author1=Ladislav Miko |author2=Jan Mourek |author3=Ioana N. Meleg |author4=Oana T. Moldovan |year=2013 |title=Oribatid mite fossils from pre-Quaternary sediments in Slovenian caves II. ''Amiracarus pliocennatus'' n.gen., n.sp. (Microzetidae) from Pliocene, with comments on the other species of the genus |journal=Zootaxa |volume=3670 |issue=4 |pages=557–578 |doi=10.11646/zootaxa.3670.4.8}} | Sp. nov | Valid | Miko ''et al.'' | Pliocene to Pleistocene | | {{Flag|Slovenia}} | An [[Oribatida|oribatid]] [[mite]]. | |- | ''[[Chaerilobuthus longiaculeus]]{{cite journal |author=Wilson R. Lourenço |year=2013 |title=A new species of ''Chaerilobuthus'' Lourenço & Beigel, 2011 from Cretaceous Burmese amber (Scorpiones: Chaerilobuthidae) |journal=Acta Biológica Paranaense |volume=42 |issue=1–4 |pages=1–5 |doi=10.5380/abpr.v42i1-4.35095}} | Sp. nov | Valid | Lourenço | Early Cretaceous | | {{Flag|Myanmar}} | A [[scorpion]], a species of ''[[Chaerilobuthus]]''. | |- | ''[[Friularachne]]''{{cite journal |author1=Fabio M. Dalla Vecchia |author2=Paul A. Selden |year=2013 |title=A Triassic spider from Italy |journal=Acta Palaeontologica Polonica |volume=58 |issue=2 |pages=325–330 |doi=10.4202/app.2011.0132 |url=http://app.pan.pl/article/item/app20110132.html}} | Gen. et sp. nov | Valid | Dalla Vecchia & Selden | Late Triassic (Norian) | [[Dolomia di Forni Formation]] | {{Flag|Italy}} | A member of [[Mygalomorphae]], possibly an [[Atypoidea|atypoid]]. The type species is ''Friularachne rigoi''. | |- | ''[[Gondwanascorpio emzantsiensis|Gondwanascorpio]]''{{cite journal |author=Robert W. Gess |year=2013 |title=The earliest record of terrestrial animals in Gondwana: A scorpion from the Famennian (Late Devonian) Witpoort Formation of South Africa |journal=African Invertebrates |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=373–379 |url=http://africaninvertebrates.org/ojs/index.php/AI/article/viewFile/284/252 |doi=10.5733/afin.054.0206}} | Gen. et sp. nov | Valid | Gess | Devonian ([[Famennian]]) | [[Witpoort Formation]] | {{Flag|South Africa}} | A [[scorpion]] of uncertain phylogenetic placement. The type species is ''Gondwanascorpio emzantsiensis''. | |- | ''Labidostoma (Pseudocornutella) electri''{{cite journal |author1=Ekaterina Sidorchuk |author2=Michel Bertrand |year=2013 |title=New fossil labidostomatids (Acari: Labidostomatidae) from Eocene amber and presence of an apustulate species in Europe |journal=Acarologia |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=25–39 |doi=10.1051/acarologia/20132079}} | Subgen. et sp. nov | Valid | Sidorchuk & Bertrand | Eocene | | Europe | A [[Labidostomatidae|labidostomatid]] [[mite]] found in [[Baltic amber]], a species of ''[[Labidostoma]]''. | |- | ''[[Lagonomegops|Lagonomegops? cor]]''{{cite journal |author1=Ricardo Pérez-de la Fuente |author2=Erin E. Saupe |author3=Paul A. Selden |year=2013 |title=New lagonomegopid spiders (Araneae: †Lagonomegopidae) from Early Cretaceous Spanish amber |journal=Journal of Systematic Palaeontology |volume=11 |issue=5 |pages=531–553 |doi=10.1080/14772019.2012.725679}} | Sp. nov | Validhttp://zoobank.org/References/67DF253C-4DD8-46B5-8FD4-540D53F6E90B | Pérez-de la Fuente, Saupe & Selden | Early Cretaceous (Albian) | | {{Flag|Spain}} | A [[Lagonomegopidae|lagonomegopid]] found in Albian Spanish amber, possibly a species of ''Lagonomegops''. | |- | ''[[Mongolarachne]]''{{cite journal |last1=Selden |first1=P. A. |last2=Shih |first2=C.K. |last3=Ren |first3=D. |year=2013 |title=A giant spider from the Jurassic of China reveals greater diversity of the orbicularian stem group |journal=Naturwissenschaften |volume=100 |issue=12 |pages=1171–1181 |doi=10.1007/s00114-013-1121-7 |bibcode=2013NW....100.1171S |pmid=24317464 |pmc=3889289}} | Gen. et comb. nov | Valid | Selden, Shih & Ren | Middle or Late Jurassic | | {{Flag|China}} | A member of [[Araneomorphae]] related to the group [[Orbiculariae]]; a new genus for ''"[[Nephila]]" jurassica'' Selden, Shih & Ren (2011). | |- | ''[[Permotarbus]]''{{cite journal |author1=Jason A. Dunlop |author2=Ronny Rößler |year=2013 |title=The youngest trigonotarbid ''Permotarbus schuberti'' n. gen., n. sp. from the Permian Petrified Forest of Chemnitz in Germany |journal=Fossil Record |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=229–243 |doi=10.1002/mmng.201300012}} | Gen. et sp. nov | Valid | Dunlop & Rößler | Early Permian | | {{Flag|Germany}} | A member of [[Trigonotarbida]]. The type species is ''Permotarbus schuberti''. | |- | ''Sellnickiella balticae'' | Sp. nov | Valid | Sidorchuk & Bertrand | Eocene | | Europe | A [[Labidostomatidae|labidostomatid]] [[mite]] found in [[Baltic amber]], a species of ''[[Sellnickiella]]''. | |- | ''[[Soplaogonomegops]]'' | Gen. et sp. nov | Valid | Pérez-de la Fuente, Saupe & Selden | Early Cretaceous (Albian) | | {{Flag|Spain}} | A [[Lagonomegopidae|lagonomegopid]] found in Albian Spanish amber. The type species is ''Soplaogonomegops unzuei''. | |- | ''[[Spinomegops]]'' | Gen. et 2 sp. nov | Valid | Pérez-de la Fuente, Saupe & Selden | Early Cretaceous (Albian) | | {{Flag|Spain}} | A [[Lagonomegopidae|lagonomegopid]] found in Albian Spanish amber. Genus contains two species: ''S. arcanus'' and ''S. aragonensis''. | |- | ''[[Talbragaraneus]]{{Cite journal |author1=Paul A. Selden |author2=Robert G. Beattie |year=2013 |title=A spider fossil from the Jurassic Talbragar Fossil Fish Bed of New South Wales |journal=Alcheringa: An Australasian Journal of Palaeontology |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=203–208 |doi=10.1080/03115518.2013.735072}} | Gen. et sp. nov | Valid | Selden & Beattie | Jurassic | [[Talbragar fossil site|Talbragar Fossil Fish Bed]] | {{Flag|Australia}} | A possible member of [[Uloboridae]]. page.title: Abundance of elements in Earth's crust

revision.text:
[[File:Elemental abundances.svg|thumb|400px|Abundance (atom fraction) of the chemical elements in Earth's upper continental crust as a function of atomic number. The rarest elements in the crust (shown in yellow) are not the heaviest, but are rather the siderophile (iron-loving) elements in the [[Goldschmidt classification]] of elements. These have been depleted by being relocated deeper into the Earth's core. Their abundance in [[meteoroid]]s is higher. Additionally, tellurium and selenium have been depleted from the crust due to formation of volatile hydrides.]] The '''abundance of elements in Earth's crust''' is shown in tabulated form with the estimated [[Earth's crust|crustal]] abundance for each [[chemical element]] shown as [[Parts-per notation|parts per million]] (ppm) by [[mass]] (10,000 ppm = 1%).
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: right;" |+Abundance of chemical elements in Earth's crust, from various sources ! Rank !! colspan=3 | [[Atomic number|Z]], element & symbol !! colspan=5 | Abundance in crust (ppm) by source !! Annual production |- ! ! ! ! ! Darling<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/elterr.html |title = Elements, Terrestrial Abundance |publisher = www.daviddarling.info |accessdate = 2007-04-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070410165310/http://daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/elterr.html| archivedate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> ! Barbalace<ref>{{cite web|last = Barbalace |first = Kenneth |url = http://environmentalchemistry.com/yogi/periodic/ |title = Periodic Table of Elements |publisher = Environmental Chemistry.com |accessdate = 2007-04-14}}</ref> ! WebElements<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.webelements.com/webelements/properties/text/image-flash/abund-crust.html |title = Abundance in Earth's Crust |publisher = WebElements.com |accessdate = 2007-04-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070309033534/http://www.webelements.com/webelements/properties/text/image-flash/abund-crust.html| archivedate= 9 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> ! Israel Science and Technology<ref> {{cite web |url = https://www.science.co.il/elements/?s=Earth |title = List of Periodic Table Elements Sorted by Abundance in Earth's crust |publisher = Israel Science and Technology Homepage |accessdate = 2007-04-15}}</ref> ! Jefferson Lab<ref> {{cite web |url = http://education.jlab.org/itselemental/index.html |title = It's Elemental — The Periodic Table of Elements |publisher = Jefferson Lab |accessdate = 2007-04-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070429032414/http://education.jlab.org/itselemental/index.html| archivedate= 29 April 2007| deadurl= no}}</ref> ! (2016, [[tonnes]])<ref>[http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/ Commodity Statistics and Information]. USGS. All production numbers are for mines, except for Al, Cd, Fe, Ge, In, N, Se (plants, refineries), S (all forms) and As, Br, Mg, Si (unspecified). Data for B, K, Ti, Y are given not for the pure element but for the most common oxide, data for Na and Cl are for NaCl. For many elements like Si, Al, data are ambiguous (many forms produced) and are taken for the pure element. U data is pure element required for consumption by current reactor fleet [http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Facts-and-Figures/World-Nuclear-Power-Reactors-and-Uranium-Requirements/]. WNA.</ref> |- | 1 | 8 | [[oxygen]] | O | 466,000 | 474,000 | 460,000 | 467,100 | 461,000 | |- | 2 | 14 | [[silicon]] | Si | 277,200 | 277,100 | 270,000 | 276,900 | 282,000 |7,200,000 |- | 3 | 13 | [[aluminium]] | Al | 81,300 | 82,000 | 82,000 | 80,700 | 82,300 |57,600,000 |- | 4 | 26 | [[iron]] | Fe | 50,000 | 41,000 | 63,000 | 50,500 | 56,300 |1,150,000,000 |- | 5 | 20 | [[calcium]] | Ca | 36,300 | 41,000 | 50,000 | 36,500 | 41,500 | |- | 6 | 11 | [[sodium]] | Na | 28,300 | 23,000 | 23,000 | 27,500 | 23,600 |255,000,000 |- | 7 | 12 | [[magnesium]] | Mg | 20,900 | 23,000 | 29,000 | revision.text:
{{About|the computer game series|the travel-reality series|Backpackers (TV series){{!}}''Backpackers'' (TV series)|the comedy series|Backpackers (web series){{!}}''Backpackers'' (web series)}} {{Orphan|date=September 2011}} {{Expand Danish|Backpacker (spil-serie)|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox video game series | title = Backpacker | image = Backpacker.jpg | caption = Cover for ''Backpacker'' | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[Mac OS]] | developer = TATI Mixedia
Aniware AB
Pan Vision AB | publisher = BMG Interactive
Pan Vision AB | genre = Quiz, [[Adventure game|Adventure]] | spinoffs = | first release version = ''Backpacker'' | first release date = 1995 | latest release version = ''Backpacker 3 - The Collection'' | latest release date = 2006 }} '''''Backpacker''''' is a series of Swedish [[Personal computer game|computer games]]. The games are travel simulators where the player travels the world and answers questions. The graphics in the games consists mostly of static images. The series has never been released for game consoles. The series was originally developed by Tati Mixedia and Aniware AB and published by BMG Interactive. After ''Backpacker 2'', Pan Vision AB took over the series. ==Gameplay== The game is about traveling around to different cities in the world and answering questions about the locations. In order to get the money needed for traveling, the player have to take different jobs. There can be several different goals in the game. Either that travel around the world in the shortest time to visit as many cities as possible or to get certificates in as many jobs as possible. In ''Backpacker 3'' there are also other missions. ==''Backpacker''== ''Backpacker'' was released in 1995 on one CD-ROM. The game was developed by Stefan Gadnell and Jens Thorsen. ==''Backpacker 2''== ''Backpacker 2'' was released in 1997 on two CD-ROMs. As of 2010, it had sold 600,000 copies in the [[Nordic countries]]. The game contains 70 destinations, 70 different jobs and 6,000 questions. It has two difficulty levels, Tourist and Globetrotter. ==''Backpacker 3''== ''Backpacker 3'' was released on 24 October 2003 by Pan Vision AB. It is programmed in [[Adobe Director|Macromedia director]]. The game includes 100 destinations and 9,000 questions. There are different levels of difficulty to the questions so that both adults and children can play. The game received a positive review and a rating of 4/5 by the newspaper [[Aftonbladet]], its readers gave a rating of 3.45/5 (as of March 2011). The graphics was criticized in a review in the newspaper [[Expressen]]. It was the eighth best-selling video game in Sweden in 2003. ===Expansions=== Two expansion packs were released in 2004. ''Backpacker 3: Mediterraneo'' includes 15 new destinations in the [[Mediterranean Basin|Mediterranean region]] and contains 2,100 questions. ''Backpacker 3: Americana'' includes 15 new destinations in and around the United States, and contains 2,600 questions. In 2006, ''Backpacker 3'' and the two expansion packs was released in a collection box. ==Titles== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Game ! Date ! Publisher ! Ref(s) |- | ''Backpacker'' | 1995 | BMG Interactive | |- | ''Backpacker 2'' | 1997 | BMG Interactive | |- | ''Backpacker Junior'' | 1997 | Vision Park AB | |- | ''Backpacker 3'' | 24 October 2003 | Pan Vision AB | |- | ''Backpacker 3: Mediterraneo'' | 29 October 2004 | Pan Vision AB | |- | ''Backpacker 3: Americana'' | 29 October 2004 | Pan Vision AB | |- | ''Backpacker 3 - The Collection'' | 16 January 2006 | Pan Vision AB | |} ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker |title=Backpacker |publisher=[[MobyGames]] |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker-2 |title=Backpacker 2 |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker-junior |title=Backpacker Junior |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker-3 |title=Backpacker 3 |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/backpacker-3-mediterraneo |title=Backpacker 3: Mediterraneo |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker-3-americana |title=Backpacker 3: Americana |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/backpacker-3-the-collection |title=Backpacker 3 - The Collection |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web |url=http://www.dataspelsbranschen.se/media/113552/dsb_gamedeveloperindex09-screenview.pdf |title=Game Developer Index 2009 |year=2010 |publisher=Dataspelsbranschen |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.panvision.com/1/1.0.1.0/33/1/?item=prod_prod-s1/13227 |title=Backpacker 3 - The Collection |year=2011 |publisher=Pan Vision AB |accessdate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321090315/http://www.panvision.com/1/1.0.1.0/33/1/?item=prod_prod-s1%2F13227 |archivedate=21 March 2012 |df= }} {{cite news |title=Res jorden runt på din dator |first=Henrik |last=Rudin |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/spela/recensioner/article172110.ab |newspaper=[[Aftonbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=24 October 2003 |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite news |title=Backpacker 3 |first=Ingemar |last=Falk |url=http://www.expressen.se/noje/recensioner/spel/1.56035/backpacker-3 |newspaper=[[Expressen]] |language=Swedish |date=22 October 2003 |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite news |title=Backpacker 3 får tilläggspaket |first=Jan |last=Sandbladh |url=http://pcforalla.idg.se/2.1054/1.69754 |newspaper=PC för Alla |language=Swedish |date=13 November 2003 |accessdate=13 March 2011}} {{cite news |title=Sims toppar listan |url=http://www.idg.se/2.1085/1.26768 |publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG Sweden]] |language=Swedish |date=22 October 2004 |accessdate=19 March 2011}} {{cite news |title=Historia och nutid med spel på museum |url=http://computersweden.idg.se/2.2683/1.141034 |first=Pär |last=Rittsel |publisher=Computer Sweden |language=Swedish |date=21 January 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011}} {{cite news |title=Lärorik fotvandring är inne på åttonde året |url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/larorik-fotvandring-ar-inne-pa-attonde-aret_110992.svd |first=Erik |last=Bergin |newspaper=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=27 September 2003 |accessdate=19 March 2011}} }} ==External links== *{{MobyGames|id=-group/backpacker-series|name=The ''Backpacker'' series}} [[Category:Quiz video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]] [[Category:Video game franchises]] [[Category:Video game franchises introduced in 1995]] [[Category:Earth in fiction]]
